item.title: Professor Ordered to Pay 9 Who Said ‘Comfort Women’ Book Defamed Them
item.description: A South Korean court said Park Yu-ha must pay $8,262 to each woman for defaming them with “false” and “distorted” content in her book.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Park Yu-ha, a professor of Japanese literature at Sejong University, in Seoul, South Korea. A court ordered her to pay $8,262 to each of nine women who had filed suit claiming that her book had defamed them.

item.title: United Nations Memo: U.S. Record on Refugees Reflects Domestic and Global Challenges
item.description: The political costs of accepting refugees are high. And President Obama’s goal of taking in 10,000 Syrians this year faces difficulties.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian Kurdish women, carrying their belongings on their heads, arrived in Yumurtalik, Turkey, in 2014.

item.title: Turkey Makes Arrest Over Istanbul Suicide Bombing
item.description: The interior minister, who said that one person was held in connection with the attack that killed 10 German tourists, provided no details about the suspect.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and VICTOR HOMOLA
item.media:description: Interior Minister Thomas De Maizière of Germany, center, with his Turkish counterpart, Efkan Ala, right, in Istanbul on Wednesday.

item.title: China Arrests Rights Lawyer and Her Husband on Subversion Charges
item.description: The filing of such charges against Wang Yu and Bao Longjun continues the state’s aggressive crackdown against challenges to Communist Party rule.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The lawyer Wang Yu during an interview in Beijing in April. The subversion charge she faces could lead to a life sentence, said her lawyer, Li Yuhan.

item.title: Gunfire and Bombing Near Pakistani Consulate in Afghanistan Kill 7
item.description: Eleven people were injured in the blast in the eastern city of Jalalabad.
item.dc:creator: KHALID ALOKOZAY and MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Two schoolgirls were helped near the Pakistani Consulate in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, after a deadly explosion and a gun fight on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Releases U.S. Sailors Accused of ‘Trespassing’
item.description: An investigation found that the entry into Iranian waters was the result of navigation-system failure, Iranian state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK, HELENE COOPER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Mc1 Latunya Howard/U.S. Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A boat similar to the one Iran seized in the Persian Gulf on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli Air Force Conducts Strike Along Gaza Border
item.description: It hit what the military said was a squad of Palestinian militants planning to attack Israeli forces in the area with a bomb.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere: The Taiwan Elections: What to Expect
item.description: Tsai Ing-wen of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party may become Taiwan’s first female president, and the governing Kuomintang could lose control of the legislature.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The presidential candidates — from left, James Soong, Eric Chu and Tsai Ing-wen — before their first televised debate last month.

item.title: Suicide Bomb Near Polio Center in Pakistan Kills at Least 16
item.description: Thirteen of the victims were police officers, an official said, and the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
item.dc:creator: IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD
item.media:description: Security officials examining the site of a suicide bombing outside a polio vaccination center in Quetta, Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Desna Journal: Glass Beads Made in Czech Village Adorn Bodies of the World’s Tribes
item.description: Glittering glass beads produced at the Preciosa factory in Desna can be found across the world, a favorite of the Masai and Samburu tribes in Kenya and Tanzania, and the Kayapos of the Amazon.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker scooped molten glass out of a furnace at the Preciosa Ornela glass-bead factory in Desna.

item.title: Belgium Identifies 3 Houses Used to Prepare for Paris Attacks
item.description: Investigators found bomb-making material and traces of an explosive used in the Nov. 13 assaults, as well as fingerprints of three suspects.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WOLGELENTER

item.title: A Climate of Fear Widens Divisions in Europe’s Migrant Crisis
item.description: Anti-immigration groups and right-wing extremists have seized on a wave of assaults in Cologne, Germany, on New Year’s Eve to discredit all migrants as criminals or hooligans.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: South Korea Presses China for More Aggressive Action on the North
item.description: The response, from President Park Geun-hye, came as criticism of her policy of building stronger ties with Beijing mounted.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea giving a televised speech on Wednesday. “China has repeatedly said publicly that it would not tolerate North Korea’s nuclear weapons,” she said.

item.title: Iran Seizes U.S. Sailors Amid Claims of Spying
item.description: American officials said that the military had lost contact with the boats in the Persian Gulf and that Iran had promised to return the sailors soon.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: A boat of the type seized by Iran in the Persian Gulf on Tuesday. The sailors aboard are expected to be returned soon.

item.title: North Korea Faked Test Video, Group Says
item.description: The footage North Korea has broadcast of what looked like a successful submarine-launched ballistic missile was most likely faked to exaggerate the country’s advances in missile development
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Actors Who Met El Chapo Are Not Targets of Inquiry
item.description: The Mexican government said Tuesday evening that it would not be investigating the actors Sean Penn or Kate del Castillo.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Rebuilding of Nepali Homes Hit by Quakes Is Still Delayed, Official Says
item.description: The reconstruction of houses destroyed in earthquakes will not begin until April, a year after the first tremors hit, a Nepali official has said.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Houses, damaged in April during earthquakes in Bhaktapur, Nepal, were still in disrepair last month. Preliminary government estimates suggest that around 570,000 homes were destroyed and nearly 270,000 badly damaged.

item.title: Persian (or Arabian) Gulf Is Caught in the Middle of Regional Rivalries
item.description: As tensions escalate between Iran and Saudi Arabia, a dispute over the name of the body of water between them illustrates the disagreements at the heart of their dispute.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt in the Persian Gulf last year. The name of the gulf has been disputed by Iran and Arab countries including Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Protests Resume in São Paulo
item.description: The police broke up a demonstration in Brazil’s financial capital against an increase in bus and transit fares amid a prolonged recession.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: U.S. Church Puts 5 Banks From Israel on a Blacklist
item.description: The United Methodist Church has placed five Israeli banks on a list of companies that it will not invest in for human rights reasons.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
